greeting: Greetings from The On-Line Encyclopedia of Integer Sequences! http://oeis.org/

results.name: Array T(m,n) read by antidiagonals: number of domino tilings (or dimer tilings) of the m X n grid (or m X n rectangle), for m>=1, n>=1.
comment: There are many versions of this array (or triangle) in the OEIS. This is the main entry, which ideally collects together all the references to the literature and to other versions in the OEIS. But see A004003 for further information. - _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 14 2015
reference: S. R. Finch, Mathematical Constants, Cambridge, 2003, pp. 406-412.

Index entries for sequences related to dominoes
formula: If m, n even then T(m, n) = Prod(j=1..m/2, Prod(k=1..n/2, 4*cos(j*Pi/(m+1))^2 + 4*cos(k*Pi/(n+1))^2)).
maple: (Maple code for the even-numbered rows from _N. J. A. Sloane_, Mar 15 2015. This is not totally satisfactory since it uses floating point. However, it is useful for getting the initial values quickly.)
z:=proc(h,d) global p; evalf(cos( h*p/(2*d+1) )); end;
T:=proc(m,n) global z; round(mul( mul( 4*z(h,m)^2+4*z(k,n)^2, k=1..n), h=1..m)); end;
mathematica: t[m_, n_] := Product[2*(2 + Cos[2j*Pi/(m+1)] + Cos[2k*Pi/(n+1)]), {k, 1, n/2}, {j, 1, m/2}]; t[_?OddQ, _?OddQ] = 0; Flatten[ Table[ FullSimplify[ t[m-n+1, n]], {m, 1, 12}, {n, 1, m}]](* _Jean-François Alcover_, Nov 25 2011 *)
program: (PARI) {T(n, k) = sqrtint(abs(polresultant(polchebyshev(n, 2, x/2), polchebyshev(k, 2, I*x/2))))} \\ _Seiichi Manyama_, Apr 13 2020
xref: See A187596 for another version (with m >= 0, n >= 0). See A187616 for a triangular version. See also A187617, A187618.
See also A004003 for more literature on the dimer problem.
